newsitem.title: FRANCE: Juppe pledges "greater firmness" in Corsica.
newsitem.headline: Juppe pledges "greater firmness" in Corsica.

text.p: French Prime Minister Alain Juppe told parliament on Tuesday he had ordered a policy of "greater firmness" towards separatist violence in Corsica and called for a national mobilisation to fight terrorism.

Speaking three days after Corsican militants set off a bomb at his mayoral office in Bordeaux, Juppe said: "With the full approval of the president, I have renewed orders of greater firmness to the interior and justice ministers."
"To defeat this curse of violence and terrorism, the only effective remedy is the mobilisation, solidarity and cohesion of all of us," he said.
Juppe said the main hardline separatist group, the Historic Wing of the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC), had rejected his offer of dialogue and chosen "radicalisation".
Reinforcement of police and justice investigators in Corsica had already yielded first results, with more than 20 bomb suspects arrested, and the government would stick to its course.

At the same time, Juppe vowed to pursue a generous policy of economic, social and cultural development on the poor Medterranean island, which suffers from higher unemployment and a lower average income than mainland France.
The prime minister said he was convinced that the vast majority of Corsicans wanted peace and quiet to enable the economic development of their region.
